name: TheAtlantic
text: "Even when wealthy people encounter misfortune on-screen, they’re suffering on yachts." Hannah Giorgis on HBO's "The Undoing" and the tricky allure of shows about ultrarich people who do bad things: https://t.co/2CtNv7EAIe

name: TheAtlantic
text:
On this episode of the podcast Social Distance, Diane Whitmore Schanzenbach, an economist at Northwestern University, describes a dire situation for poor Americans and a tremendous need for new relief funding:
https://t.co/9Hgw4MJUf0 https://t.co/20ElJTIaxA

name: TheAtlantic
text: Sarah Cooper went viral for lip-synching the president. But in her new Netflix special, "Everything's Fine," she demonstrates a weirder—and darker—comedic taste, writes @shirklesxp: https://t.co/zg672BnQbC

name: TheAtlantic
text: Here are three things to know about the present condition of the pandemic-ravaged economy. The latest Atlantic Daily, by @mimbsy: https://t.co/kmR7M0OZtr

name: TheAtlantic
text: Sign up for the newsletter here: https://t.co/Wb8dTx1YGA

name: TheAtlantic
text: Joe Biden needs to win Catholic voters to reach the White House. Will his Scranton bona fides be enough? @emmaogreen reports: https://t.co/vjuxgVWak8

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Trump is getting off easy for a series of recent scandals, most likely because press outlets have concluded that he is doomed and that coverage is largely pointless," writes @GrahamDavidA: https://t.co/tXmwEUG35v

name: TheAtlantic
text: The U.S. has seen what happens when a pandemic occurs under Trump. If he is reelected, he will continue on the same path, and so will the coronavirus, writes @edyong209: https://t.co/lek0DGeBMd

name: TheAtlantic
text: Related: Last month, @edyong209 detailed nine conceptual errors that are keeping the U.S. trapped in the pandemic: https://t.co/oE10psdES7

name: TheAtlantic
text: "A defeated and vindictive Trump could well find many ways to make the time between the election’s resolution and the inauguration a national nightmare. But the real threats will be out in the open," @kateashaw1 and @michaeleherz write: https://t.co/sNlqWRLL3u

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Choose the candidate who will be the better influence," @conor64 writes: https://t.co/g3WoMlJcjF

name: TheAtlantic
text: Waiting in line was always annoying, but the pandemic made it unsafe, too. Now technology could finally kill queues for good, writes @elissavetam: https://t.co/HfxALpBnSE

name: TheAtlantic
text: A personal appeal can change a loved one's vote, @jpinsk writes. But while the odds of influencing election results are extremely low, the odds of changing your relationship with that person are much higher. https://t.co/c5hLR3rKMN

name: TheAtlantic
text: Praying for rain in August isn’t enough. Playing offense every fire season isn't enough, either. The federal program of prescribed burning isn't set up to do the work it needs to, and maybe simply can't be, @amonthei writes: https://t.co/XT5Rxeqkxd

name: TheAtlantic
text: "If the American people elect a president who is willing to do bad things, the only thing that can stop him is the American people." @GrahamDavidA on what the author of an anonymous op-ed got wrong: https://t.co/XxwKqdf6ca

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YAppelbaum: Anonymous’s revelation is also a confession, writes @GrahamDavidA. He failed, because he was wrong: https://t.co/X6v6l9qnLn

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @jpinsk: I interviewed 20+ voters and two political scientists to put together this guide for persuading a loved one to vote a certain way. 

Just in case anyone needs that right now.

My latest in @TheAtlantic:

https://t.co/aIPPd0bJnD

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @ibogost: When @alexismadrigal and I dug deep into Facebook political ads last winter, this was precisely what we couldn’t access and analyze. How the ads were targeted. Absent that knowledge, it’s almost meaningless to be “transparent” with thousands of ads.

https://t.co/ksJJB1GQh2

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @davidfrum: I wrote this about "Anonymous" in 2018 https://t.co/GZVezCF9iR https://t.co/M34E8yW7Ov

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: I just learned so much about the history and behavioral science of waiting in line. Fascinating in the best way—a cultural and psychological portrait of something I never thought deeply about before: https://t.co/UCFzB3plzo

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @julieebeck: I’ve been wondering, pretty much since 2016, whether anyone out there has actually changed a loved one’s mind on politics, and if so how they did it. @jpinsk answers that question, but these convos turn out to be more about the relationship than the vote:
https://t.co/qyuyQC6vpa

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @kait_tiffany: i wrote about the way conspiracy theories are spreading through MLMs, aided by a business model that incentivizes relentless posting, hampered only slightly by facebook's efforts to wipe out QAnon earlier this month 

https://t.co/hStioYbeXC

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @MaryStachyra: I've believed for years that no secular journalist understands and writes about religion better than @emmaogreen. A fascinating look at the tensions within modern Catholicism, and what they could mean for the Biden campaign:
https://t.co/Q6jaN1rds6
